front.title: JSCalendar: Converting from and to iCalendar

abstract.t: This document defines how to convert calendaring information between the JSCalendar and iCalendar data formats. It considers every JSCalendar and iCalendar element registered at IANA at the time of publication. It defines conversion rules for all elements that are common to both formats, as well as how convert arbitrary or unknown JSCalendar and iCalendar elements.

note.t: This document is unfinished. The term TBD stands for any unknown item.

section.name: Notational Conventions
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCPÂ 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.
The ABNF definitions in this document use the notations of . ABNF rules not defined in this document either are defined in or .

section.name: Scope and Goals
section.t: This document outlines how to convert calendaring information between the iCalendar and JSCalendar data formats. It describes which elements are common to both, but also highlights where the two formats differ. For each common element, it defines a conversion rule and includes an example of how to convert that element. All iCalendar and JSCalendar elements currently registered at IANA are in scope, but not all of these elements are common to both formats.

For elements that have no counterpart in the other format, it is the goal of this document to define how to preserve them during conversion, but in general it is not the goal to achieve this by defining new standard elements. Instead, this document defines special-purpose properties to preserve arbitrary elements. These conversion-specific properties are defined in Section for iCalendar, and Sections and for JSCalendar. further outlines the discrepancies between the two formats.

section.name: How to Read the Examples
section.t: Later sections contain examples that illustrate how to convert between the iCalendar and JSCalendar data formats. The notation of these examples is such that their main points should be clear to the reader, but their contents can also be parsed for automated testing. The following sections define the notation for such examples.

section.name: iCalendar Examples
section.t: An iCalendar example contains either an extract or a complete representation of iCalendar data. It always represents an iCalendar object, even if the example only depicts non-VCALENDAR components or properties. The following rules apply:

ul.li: An example that only contains iCalendar properties implicitly represents a VEVENT component that is part of a VCALENDAR component.
An example that only contains one or more non-VCALENDAR components implicitly represents a VCALENDAR component that contains them.
An example that only contains a VCALENDAR component but no contained components implicitly represents a VCALENDAR component that contains a VEVENT component.
Implicit components (those without a BEGIN and END, or omitted completely) are assumed to contain all mandatory properties with some value, but the actual value is irrelevant for the example.

section.t: contains three examples, all of which represent the same iCalendar data. In the first example, both the VEVENT component and VCALENDAR component are implicit. In the second example, only the VCALENDAR component and its mandatory properties are implicit. The third example depicts a complete VCALENDAR component, nothing is implicit.

figure.name: Examples for implicit and explicit iCalendar component notation
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VEVENT DTSTAMP:20060102T030405Z DTSTART:20060102T030405Z SUMMARY:hello UID:CC0A494A-6E07-4827-8294-0752DD1ECFA4 END:VEVENT
BEGIN:VCALENDAR PRODID:-//FOO//bar//EN VERSION:2.0 BEGIN:VEVENT DTSTAMP:20060102T030405Z DTSTART:20060102T030405Z SUMMARY:hello UID:CC0A494A-6E07-4827-8294-0752DD1ECFA4 END:VEVENT END:VCALENDAR

section.t: A line containing just the value ... stands for any other properties that might be present in a component but are irrelevant for this example. This includes mandatory properties as described for implicit components. The line ... at the end of the example additionally stands for any END content lines to complete components that started with BEGIN content lines, and any of their missing mandatory properties. illustrates this as an alternative representation for the examples of .

figure.name: Example for additional properties and component ENDs represented by ...

section.t: A line starting with a single space represents the continuation of a folded content line (). illustrates this.

figure.name: Example for a folded content line

section.name: JSCalendar Examples
section.t: A JSCalendar example always represents a Group object, even if the example only depicts one of the Group entries or properties.

JSCalendar objects are depicted either explicitly or implicitly. An explicit JSCalendar object starts and ends with braces. An implicit JSCalendar object omits braces, it only consists of JSON name/value pairs, separated by comma.

An implicit JSCalendar object is assumed to be of type Event, unless it contains the @type property with a different value. It is assumed to contain all mandatory properties with some value; if they are not depicted, their actual value is irrelevant for the main point of the example.

illustrates this with multiple examples, all of which represent the same JSCalendar data. The first example contains an implicit JSCalendar object of type Event. The second example contains an implicit JSCalendar object with a @type property. The third example contains an explicit Event object but the Group object containing it is omitted. The fourth example contains the full Group object, nothing is omitted.

figure.name: Examples for implicit and explicit JSCalendar object notation

section.t: A property with name "..." and value "" stands for additional properties that might be present in a JSCalendar object, but which are irrelevant for this example. This includes mandatory properties. illustrates this as an alternative representation for the examples of .

figure.name: Example for additional properties represented by ...

section.name: iCalendar Objects
section.t: allows for an iCalendar stream to contain one or more iCalendar objects. In contrast, this specification only defines conversion for streams consisting of a single iCalendar object. Converting streams of multiple iCalendar objects is implementation-specific. All following sections of this document use the terms "iCalendar object" and "VCALENDAR component" interchangeably.
The VCALENDAR component converts to a Group object.
Its properties convert as follows:
Its components convert as follows:
Other properties or components MAY be converted to the "iCalComponent" property of the Group object.
The order of elements in the "entries" property is implementation-specific, e.g. entries need not be in the same order as their source components in the iCalendar object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the VCALENDAR component:

figure.name: Converting the VCALENDAR component

section.name: Recurring Components
section.t: Components in an iCalendar object generally convert to distinct JSCalendar objects. For example, two VEVENT components with different UID property values in the same iCalendar object convert to two separate Event objects in the Group object's entries. As an exception to this rule, this does not apply to recurrence overrides, defined as follows.

A VEVENT (or VTODO) component is a recurrence override if it has the RECURRENCE-ID property set, and the iCalendar object contains a VEVENT (or VTODO) component that does not have the RECURRENCE-ID but the RRULE property set, and the UID property values of the two components are equal. The component without the RECURRENCE-ID property is in that case referred to as the "main component".
The main component converts to an entry in the Group object's entries property.

The recurrence override converts to the "recurrenceOverrides" property of the converted main component. Its RECURRENCE-ID property value converts to the key in the "recurrenceOverrides" property. The value of the "recurrenceOverrides" property at that key is a PatchObject that transform the converted main component into the converted recurrence override. The recurrenceId and recurrenceIdTimeZone properties MUST NOT be set in the PatchObject.
The following example illustrates how to convert a main component and its recurrence override:

figure.name: Converting VEVENT recurrence overrides
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VCALENDAR BEGIN:VEVENT UID:F4257E1D-5461-4EF6-840F-9DFC653EB559 RRULE:FREQ=DAILY DTSTART;TZID=Europe/Berlin:20240101T140000 ... END:VEVENT BEGIN:VEVENT UID:F4257E1D-5461-4EF6-840F-9DFC653EB559 RECURRENCE-ID;TZID=Europe/Berlin:20240202T140000 DTSTART;TZID=Europe/Berlin:20240202T160000 ... END:VEVENT END:VCALENDAR

section.t: A VEVENT (or VTODO) component is a stand-alone recurrence instance if it has the RECURRENCE-ID property set and the iCalendar object does not contain its related main component. Each stand-alone recurrence instance converts to a distinct Event (or Task) object in the Group object's entries property. The recurrenceId property MUST be set, the "recurrenceIdTimeZone" property MUST be set if not "null".
The following example illustrates how to convert stand-alone recurrence instances:

figure.name: Converting VEVENT recurrence instances
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VCALENDAR BEGIN:VEVENT UID:F4257E1D-5461-4EF6-840F-9DFC653EB559 RECURRENCE-ID;TZID=Europe/Berlin:20240202T140000 DTSTART;TZID=Europe/Berlin:20240202T160000 ... END:VEVENT BEGIN:VEVENT UID:F4257E1D-5461-4EF6-840F-9DFC653EB559 RECURRENCE-ID;TZID=Europe/Berlin:20240103T140000 DTSTART;TZID=Europe/Berlin:20240103T170000 ... END:VEVENT END:VCALENDAR

section.name: JSCalendar Ids
section.t: JSCalendar generally uses JSON objects to represent a collection of same-typed values. The keys are of type Id, the values are JSCalendar object types. If an iCalendar element converts to a value in such a collection, then an implementation needs to choose an identifier as key.

This document defines the new JSCALID parameter and JSCALID property, which allow to set a JSCalendar Id value when converting from JSCalendar to iCalendar. If they are set on a property or the component, then its value MUST be used as key when converting that element from iCalendar to JSCalendar. If no such parameter or property is set, then an implementation is free to choose any identifier, as long the following requirements are met:

ul.li: The identifier MUST be a valid Id value.
The identifiers for the exact same iCalendar element MUST stay the same, irrespective of the order in which components, properties and parameters are processed.

section.name: Timezone identifiers
section.t: Converting temporal properties such as DTSTART, DTEND, and RECURRENCE-ID requires to not only determine the date and time of the property value, but also the timezone it references.
If the property value data type is DATE or DATE-TIME in FORM #1: DATE WITH LOCAL TIME then the timezone identifier is the JSON null value in JSCalendar.
If the property value data type is DATE-TIME in FORM #2: DATE WITH UTC TIME then the timezone identifier is the string "Etc/UTC" in JSCalendar.
If the property value data type is DATE-TIME in FORM #3: DATE WITH LOCAL TIME AND TIME ZONE REFERENCE then the timezone identifier is determined by the TZID parameter value:
If the TZID parameter value is equal to a name in the IANA Time Zone Database then the timezone identifier is that verbatim name.

If the TZID parameter value is unequal to an IANA timezone name then implementations MAY determine the name of an IANA timezone which has the same timezone rules over the timespan of the calendar object. Otherwise, the non-IANA timezone identifier is represented in JSCalendar as a string starting with the / (SLASH) character, followed by the TZID parameter value. The corresponding VTIMEZONE MUST be converted to the "timeZones" property with the prefixed identifier as key. See for an example.

section.name: DATE and DATE-TIME
section.t: iCalendar provides the DATE and DATE-TIME value types to distinguish date-only from date-time values. JSCalendar only supports date-time values. A property value of type DATE-TIME converts to either a LocalDateTime or UTCDateTime, depending on the JSCalendar property definition. A DATE value type converts to a LocalDateTime with zero time.

section.name: PARTICIPANT
section.t: The PARTICIPANT component converts to a Participant object.
Its properties convert as follows:
Its components convert as follows:
Other properties or components MAY be converted to the "iCalComponent" property of the Participant object. This includes mandatory properties such as UID.
The following example illustrates how to convert the PARTICIPANT component:

figure.name: Converting the PARTICIPANT component
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VEVENT BEGIN:PARTICIPANT UID:47AD2E1C-49D4-45DF-BD83-8398ACC7D8E2 STRUCTURED-DATA;VALUE=URI: http://dir.example.com/vcard/contacts/contact1.vcf PARTICIPANT-TYPE:CONTACT DESCRIPTION:A contact END:PARTICIPANT ...

section.name: VALARM
section.t: The VALARM component converts to an Alert object.
Its properties convert as follows:

tr.td: Only if ACTION is EMAIL or DISPLAY.

section.t: Other properties or components MAY be converted to the "iCalComponent" property of the Alert object. This includes mandatory properties such as ATTENDEE, DESCRIPTION, or SUMMARY.
The following example illustrates how to convert the VALARM component:

figure.name: Converting the VALARM component
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VEVENT BEGIN:VALARM TRIGGER:-PT30M ACTION:DISPLAY DESCRIPTION:Breakfast meeting END:VALARM ...

section.name: VEVENT
section.t: The VEVENT component converts to a Event object.
Its properties convert as follows:
Its components convert as follows:
Other properties or components MAY be converted to the "iCalComponent" property of the Event object.
VEVENT components with different UID property values in the same iCalendar object convert to different entries in the Group. They sort in the same order as in the VCALENDAR component.
The following example illustrates how to convert the VEVENT component:

figure.name: Converting the VEVENT component
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VCALENDAR BEGIN:VEVENT UID:DE935D01-3DF7-4201-B61A-D77D05C8B21A DTSTART:20060102T030405Z ... END:VEVENT BEGIN:VEVENT UID:60BE3D6E-6383-473A-BCF1-3C43EA1FA571 ... END:VEVENT END:VCALENDAR

section.name: VLOCATION
section.t: The VLOCATION component converts to a Location object.
Its properties convert as follows:
Other properties or components MAY be converted to the "iCalComponent" property of the Location object. This includes mandatory properties such as UID.
The following example illustrates how to convert the VLOCATION component:

figure.name: Converting the VLOCATION component
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VLOCATION UID:4954DC22-5BD6-4E98-844D-0302982F54AC NAME:The venue STRUCTURED-DATA;VALUE=URI: http://dir.example.com/venues/big-hall.vcf END:VLOCATION

section.name: VRESOURCE
section.t: The VRESOURCE component converts to a Participant object. The kind property value of the Participant object MUST be "resource".
Its properties convert as follows:
Other properties or components MAY be converted to the "iCalComponent" property of the Participant object. This includes mandatory properties such as UID.
The following example illustrates how to convert the VRESOURCE component:

figure.name: Converting the VRESOURCE component
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VEVENT BEGIN:VRESOURCE UID:456789-abcdef-98765432 NAME:The projector RESOURCE-TYPE:PROJECTOR STRUCTURED-DATA;VALUE=URI:http://dir.example.com/projectors/3d.vcf END:VRESOURCE ...

section.name: VTIMEZONE
section.t: The VTIMEZONE component converts to a TimeZone object.
Its properties convert as follows:
Its components convert as follows:
Other properties or components MAY be converted to the "iCalComponent" property of the TimeZone object.
The DAYLIGHT component and STANDARD component convert to a TimeZoneRule object.
Their properties convert as follows:

table.name: Properties of the DAYLIGHT or STANDARD component

section.t: Other properties or components MAY be converted to the "iCalComponent" property of the TimeZoneRule object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the VTIMEZONE component:

figure.name: Converting the VTIMEZONE component
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VCALENDAR BEGIN:VTIMEZONE TZID:CustomTz TZID-ALIAS-OF:Puerto_Rico TZID-ALIAS-OF:America/Anguilla LAST-MODIFIED:20240909T122233Z TZUNTIL:20080709T000000Z TZURL:https://example.com/tz/CustomTz.ics BEGIN:DAYLIGHT TZNAME:AWT TZOFFSETFROM:-0400 TZOFFSETTO:-0300 DTSTART:19420503T000000 END:DAYLIGHT BEGIN:DAYLIGHT TZNAME:APT TZOFFSETFROM:-0300 TZOFFSETTO:-0300 DTSTART:19450814T200000 END:DAYLIGHT BEGIN:STANDARD TZNAME:AST TZOFFSETFROM:-0300 TZOFFSETTO:-0400 DTSTART:19450930T020000 END:STANDARD END:VTIMEZONE BEGIN:VEVENT DTSTART;TZID=CustomTz:20080708T130000 ...

section.name: VTODO
section.t: The VTODO component converts to a Task object.
Its properties convert as follows:
Its components convert as follows:
Other properties or components MAY be converted to the "iCalComponent" property of the Task object.
VTODO components with different UID property values in the same iCalendar object convert to different entries in the Group. They sort in the same order as in the VCALENDAR component.
The following example illustrates how to convert the VTODO component:

figure.name: Converting the VTODO component

section.name: ACKNOWLEDGED
section.t: The ACKNOWLEDGED property in a VALARM component converts to the "acknowledged" property of the Alert object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the ACKNOWLEDGED property:

figure.name: Converting the ACKNOWLEDGED property

section.name: ACTION
section.t: The ACTION property in a VALARM component converts to the "action" property of the Alert object.
Its values convert as follows:
An ACTION property with value AUDIO or any other not listed in does not convert to the "action" property. Instead, the property converts to the iCalComponent/properties property of the Alert.
The following examples illustrate how to convert the ACTION property:

figure.name: Converting the ACTION property for value DISPLAY
Converting the ACTION property for value AUDIO

section.name: ATTACH
section.t: The ATTACH property in a VEVENT, VTODO, VRESOURCE, PARTICIPANT, or VLOCATION component converts to a Link object. The converted object is set in the "links" property of the Event, Task, Participant, or Location object.

The property value converts to the "href" property of the Link object. A value of type URI converts as-is. A value of type BINARY converts to a URI in the "data" URL scheme (. If the FMTTYPE parameter is set on the ATTACH property, then the parameter value SHOULD be set in the mediatype part of the data URL.
The ATTACH property parameters convert as follows:
The following examples illustrate how to convert the ATTACH property:

figure.name: Converting the ATTACH property with URI value
Converting the ATTACH property with BINARY value

section.name: ATTENDEE
section.t: The ATTENDEE property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to a Participant object. The converted object is set in the "participants" property of the Event or Task object.

The property value converts to both the calendarAddress and sendTo properties of the Participant object. If the CAL-ADDRESS value is in the "mailto" scheme, then it converts to the "imip" method in the "sendTo" property, otherwise it converts to the "other" method.

An ATTENDEE property and a PARTICIPANT component in the same iCalendar component convert to the same Participant object, if their converted calendarAddress property values are equal after URI normalization. How to deal with conflicting values when converting other Participant properties is implementation-specific.
The ATTENDEE property parameters convert as follows:
If no ROLE parameter is set, then the "attendee" role in the "roles" property MUST be set.

Every calendar address value of the DELEGATED-FROM, DELEGATED-TO, or MEMBER parameters converts to the identifier of a Participant object. This identifier is determined by finding that Participant object in the "participants" property, which has a calendarAddress property value matching the parameter value. If no such Participant object exists after all properties and components have been converted, then a new Participant object having that calendarAddress property value is created. If multiple Participant objects match, then choosing the Participant identifier is implementation-specific.

The PARTSTAT of an ATTENDEE property in a VTODO component converts not only to the "participationStatus" property of the Participant object, but also to its progress property if the PARTSTAT parameter value is specific for VTODO components:

table.name: Converting the PARTSTAT parameter in a VTODO component to Participant properties

section.t: The following examples illustrate how to convert the ATTENDEE property:

figure.name: Converting the ATTENDEE property
Converting the ATTENDEE property and PARTICIPANT component
Converting the ATTENDEE property with a VTODO-specific participation status

section.name: CALENDAR-ADDRESS
section.t: The CALENDAR-ADDRESS property in a PARTICIPANT component converts to the "calendarAddress" property of the Participant object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the CALENDAR-ADDRESS property:

figure.name: Converting the CALENDAR-ADDRESS property

section.name: CATEGORIES
section.t: The CATEGORIES property in a VEVENT, VTODO, or VCALENDAR component converts to the "keywords" property of the Event, Task, or Group object.

The list of category values converts to a set of keywords. The values convert case-sensitively. All CATEGORIES properties in the same iCalendar component convert to the "keywords" property in the JSCalendar object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the CATEGORIES property:

figure.name: Converting the CATEGORIES property

section.name: CLASS
section.t: The CLASS property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to the "privacy" property of the Event or Task object.
Its values convert as follows:
Any other value does not convert to the "class" property. Instead, the property converts to the iCalComponent/properties property of the JSCalendar object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the CLASS property:

figure.name: Converting the CLASS property

section.name: COLOR
section.t: The COLOR property in a VEVENT, VTODO, or VCALENDAR component converts to the "color" property of the Event, Task, or Group object.
Its value converts verbatim.
The following examples illustrate how to convert the COLOR property:

figure.name: Converting the COLOR property with color name
Converting the COLOR property with numeric value

section.name: COMMENT
section.t: The COMMENT property in a DAYLIGHT or STANDARD component converts to the "comments" property of the TimeZoneRule object.
The COMMENT property in a PARTICIPANT component converts to the "participationComment" property.

The COMMENT property in an iTIP-scheduled VEVENT or VTODO component converts to the "participationComment" property of that Participant object, which represents the source of this scheduling message, if any. It otherwise converts to the iCalComponent/properties property of the Event or Task object.

Multiple COMMENT properties in a DAYLIGHT or STANDARD component convert in any order to the multi-valued "comments" property. Converting multiple COMMENT properties to the single-valued participationComment property is implementation-specific.
The following examples illustrate how to convert the COMMENT property:

figure.name: Converting the COMMENT property in a DAYLIGHT component
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VCALENDAR BEGIN:VTIMEZONE TZID:NonIana BEGIN:DAYLIGHT TZOFFSETFROM:-0400 TZOFFSETTO:-0300 DTSTART:20010503T000000 COMMENT:take note of this COMMENT:and this END:DAYLIGHT END:VTIMEZONE ...

figure.name: Converting the COMMENT property in a PARTICIPANT component
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:PARTICIPANT UID:127ABD62-D07A-4F39-AA62-530E37A8DF78 COMMENT:I'll think about it ...

section.name: COMPLETED
section.t: The COMPLETED property in a VTODO component converts to the "completed" property of the Task object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the COMPLETED property:

figure.name: Converting the COMPLETED property

section.name: CONCEPT
section.t: The CONCEPT property in a VEVENT, VTODO, or VCALENDAR component converts to the "categories" property of the Event, Task, or Group object.
The list of URI values converts to a set of URIs. Multiple occurrences of the CONCEPT property in the same iCalendar component convert to the same categories property in the JSCalendar object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the CONCEPT property:

figure.name: Converting the CONCEPT property

section.name: CONFERENCE
section.t: The CONFERENCE property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to a VirtualLocation object. The converted object is set in the "virtualLocations" property of the Event or Task object.
The property value converts to the "uri" property of the VirtualLocation object.
Its parameters convert as follows:
The following example illustrates how to convert the CONFERENCE property:

figure.name: Converting the CONFERENCE property

section.name: CREATED
section.t: The CREATED property in a VEVENT, VTODO, or VCALENDAR component converts to the "created" property of the Event, Task, or Group object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the CREATED property:

figure.name: Converting the CREATED property

section.name: DESCRIPTION
section.t: The DESCRIPTION property in a VEVENT, VTODO, VCALENDAR, VLOCATION, VRESOURCE, or PARTICIPANT component converts to the "description" property of the Event, Task, Group, Location, Link, or Participant object, unless its DERIVED parameter value is TRUE.

If the DERIVED parameter value is TRUE, then the property does not convert to the "description" property. Instead, a non-derived STYLED-DESCRIPTION property is expected to contain the description. Implementations MAY preserve the property in the "iCalComponent" property.
The following example illustrates how to convert the DESCRIPTION property:

figure.name: Converting the DESCRIPTION property
figure.sourcecode: DESCRIPTION:The pancakes there are delicious\; they are fluffy and sweet.
"description": "The pancakes there are delicious; they are fluffy and sweet."

section.name: DTEND
section.t: The DTEND property in a VEVENT component converts to the "duration" property of the Event object.
The duration is the timespan between the points in time of the DTSTART and DTEND property values when converted to UTC time.

If the timezone identifier of the DTEND property differs from that of the DTSTART property, then the DTEND property also converts to a Location object. The timezone identifier converts to the "timeZone" property of the Location object. The relativeTo property of the Location is set to "end". The Location object is set in the "locations" property of the Event object.

Implementations MAY preserve the fact that the duration got determined by the DTEND property. How to do this depends on the timezone identifiers of the DTSTART and DTEND properties. If the identifiers are equal, then implementations MUST set the "iCalComponent" property in the Event object and there add an entry for the path "duration" in the "convertedProperties" property. If instead the timezone identifiers are not equal, then implementations MUST set the "iCalProperty" property of the Location object. In both cases, the value MUST be an ICalProperty object with the "name" property set to "dtend".
The following examples illustrate how to convert the DTEND property:

figure.name: Converting the DTEND property with same timezone
Converting the DTEND property with different timezone
Converting the DTEND property with DATE value type

section.name: DTSTAMP
section.t: The DTSTAMP property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to the "updated" property of the Event or Task object.

An Event or Task object which has the "method" property set might represent an iTIP reply of one of the participants in the object. In this case the value of the DTSTAMP property also converts to the "scheduleUpdated" property of that Participant object, which represents the participant from which the iTIP reply originated.
The DTSTAMP property in a PARTICIPANT component converts to the "scheduleUpdated" property of the Participant object.
The following examples illustrate how to convert the DTSTAMP property:

figure.name: Converting the DTSTAMP property in a VEVENT component
Converting the DTSTAMP property in a PARTICIPANT component

section.name: DTSTART
section.t: The DTSTART property in a VEVENT, VTODO, DAYLIGHT or STANDARD component converts to the "start" property of the Event, Task, or TimeZoneRule object.
See how to convert DATE and DATE-TIME values.

For VEVENT and VTODO components, the timezone identifier of the DTSTART property converts to the "timeZone" property of the Event or Task object. In addition, if the value type of the DTSTART property is DATE, then the value of the "showWithoutTime" property is "true".

The following examples illustrate how to convert the DTSTART property for the VEVENT and VTODO components. See for examples how to convert the DTSTART property for the DAYLIGHT and STANDARD components.

figure.name: Converting the DTSTART property with TZID parameter
Converting the DTSTART property with UTC time
Converting the DTSTART property with floating time
Converting the DTSTART property with value type DATE

section.name: DUE
section.t: The DUE property in a VTODO component converts to the "due" property of the Task object.
See how to convert DATE and DATE-TIME values.

If the VTODO component does not contain a DTSTART property, then the timezone identifier of the DUE property converts to the "timeZone" property of the Task object. If instead the VTODO component contains both the DUE and DTSTART properties, then the timezone identifier of the DUE property does not convert to a standard JSCalendar element. The value of the "due" property MUST denote the date and time relative to the timezone of the DTSTART property.
If the value type of the DUE property is DATE, then the value of the "showWithoutTime" property is "true".
The following examples illustrate how to convert the DUE property:

figure.name: Converting the DUE property with TZID parameter
Converting the DUE property with UTC time
Converting the DUE property with floating time
Converting the DUE property with value type DATE

section.name: DURATION
section.t: The DURATION property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to the "duration" property of the Event or Task object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the DURATION property:

figure.name: Converting the DURATION

section.name: EXDATE
section.t: The EXDATE property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to a PatchObject value. The converted object is set in the "recurrenceOverrides" property of the Event or Task object.

The property value converts to the key in the "recurrenceOverrides" property value. See how to convert DATE and DATE-TIME values. The date-time MUST be relative to the timezone identified by the "timeZone" property of the Event or Task. The PatchObject value MUST set the "excluded" property to "true" and MUST NOT set any other property.
The following example illustrates how to convert the EXDATE property:

figure.name: Converting the EXDATE property

section.name: EXRULE
section.t: The EXRULE property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to a RecurrenceRule object. The converted object is set in the "excludedRecurrenceRules" property of the Event or Task.
See for an example how to convert a recurrence rule.

section.name: GEO
section.t: The GEO property in a VEVENT, VTODO, PARTICIPANT or VRESOURCE component converts to a Location object. The converted object is set in the "locations" property of the Event, Task, or Participant object.
The GEO property in a VLOCATION component converts to the "coordinates" property of the Location object.

The pair of FLOAT values converts to a URI with the "geo" scheme. The first FLOAT value converts to the "coord-a" part of the URI, the second FLOAT value to the "coord-b" part. A preceding plus sign (+) of the FLOAT value MUST be omitted, a preceding minus sign (-) MUST be preserved. The optional "coord-c" part of the URI MUST be omitted.
The following examples illustrate how to convert the GEO property:

figure.name: Converting the GEO property in a VEVENT
Converting the GEO property in a VLOCATION

section.name: IMAGE
section.t: The IMAGE property in a VEVENT, VTODO, VLOCATION, or VRESOURCE component converts to a Link object. The converted object is set in the "links" property of the Event, Task, Location, or Participant object.

The property value converts to the "href" property of the Link object. A value of type URI converts as-is. See how to convert a BINARY value. If the DISPLAY parameter is set, then the "rel" property of the Link object MUST be set to "icon".
Its parameters convert as follows:
Implementations MAY preserve the fact that the Link object got converted from an IMAGE property. To do so, they MUST set the iCalProperty on the Link object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the IMAGE property:

figure.name: Converting the IMAGE property

section.name: LAST-MODIFIED
section.t: The LAST-MODIFIED property in a VCALENDAR or VTIMEZONE component converts to the "updated" property of the Group or TimeZone object.

The LAST-MODIFIED property in a VEVENT or VTODO component does not convert to the "updated" property of the Event or Task object. Implementations MAY instead preserve the LAST-MODIFIED property in the "iCalComponent" property.
The following example illustrates how to convert the LAST-MODIFIED property:

figure.name: Converting the IMAGE property

section.name: LINK
section.t: The LINK property of type URI in a VEVENT, VTODO, VCALENDAR, VRESOURCE, PARTICIPANT, or VLOCATION component converts to a Link object.
The converted object is set in the "links" property of the Event, Task, Group, Participant, or Location object. The LINK property value converts to the "href" property of the Link object.
Its parameters convert as follows:

A LINK property with a value type other than URI or an unregistered LINK parameter value does not convert to a standard JSCalendar element. Implementations MAY convert it to the "iCalComponent" property.
The following examples illustrate how to convert the LINK property:

figure.name: Converting the LINK property to a Link object
Converting the LINK property to iCalComponent

section.name: LOCATION
section.t: The LOCATION property in a VEVENT, VTODO, or PARTICIPANT component converts to a Location object, unless its DERIVED parameter value is TRUE. The converted object is set in the "locations" property of the Event, Task, or Participant object.
The property value converts to the "title" property of the Location object.

If the DERIVED parameter value is TRUE, then the property does not convert to a Location object. Instead, a VLOCATION component is expected to represent the location. Implementations MAY preserve the property in the "iCalComponent" property.
The following example illustrates how to convert the LOCATION property:

figure.name: Converting the LOCATION property

section.name: LOCATION-TYPE
section.t: The LOCATION-TYPE property in a VLOCATION component converts to the "locationTypes" property of the Location object.

The list of location type values converts to a set of location types. The values convert case-sensitively. All LOCATION-TYPE properties in the same VLOCATION convert to the "locationTypes" property in the Location object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the LOCATION-TYPE property:

figure.name: Converting the LOCATION property

section.name: METHOD
section.t: The METHOD property in a VCALENDAR component converts to the "method" property of all Event or Task objects that are listed in the Group object's entries property.
The property value converts in lowercase.
The following example illustrates how to convert the METHOD property:

figure.name: Converting the METHOD property

section.name: NAME
section.t: The NAME property in a VLOCATION or VRESOURCE component converts to the "name" property of the Location or Participant object.
The NAME property in a VCALENDAR component converts to the "title" property of the Group object.
The following examples illustrate how to convert the NAME property:

figure.name: Converting the NAME property in a VCALENDAR component
Converting the NAME property in the VLOCATION and VRESOURCE components
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VEVENT BEGIN:VLOCATION NAME:Room B ... END:VLOCATION BEGIN:VRESOURCE NAME:Whiteboard ... END:VRESOURCE ...

section.name: ORGANIZER
section.t: The ORGANIZER property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to the "replyTo" property of the Event or Task object. In addition, it converts to a Participant object in the "participants" property.

If the CAL-ADDRESS property value is in the "mailto" scheme, then it converts to the "imip" method in the "replyTo" property, otherwise it converts to the "other" method. The property value also converts to the "calendarAddress" property of the Participant object. The "owner" role is set in the "roles" property of the Participant. In contrast to the ATTENDEE property, the property value does not convert to the "sendTo" property of the Participant object.

An ORGANIZER property, an ATTENDEE property, and a PARTICIPANT component in the same iCalendar component all convert to the same Participant object, if their converted calendarAddress property values are equal after URI normalization. How to deal with conflicting property values is implementation-specific.

Implementations MAY preserve arbitrary parameters of the ORGANIZER property, in which case they MUST convert these to the "replyTo" entry in the "convertedProperties" property of the Event or Task object's "iCalComponent" property.
The ORGANIZER property parameters convert as follows:
The following examples illustrate how to convert the ORGANIZER property:

figure.name: Converting an ORGANIZER property
Converting an ORGANIZER and ATTENDEE property

section.name: PARTICIPANT-TYPE
section.t: The PARTICIPANT-TYPE property in a PARTICIPANT component converts to the "roles" property of the Participant object.
The property value converts in lowercase.
The following example illustrates how to convert the PARTICIPANT-TYPE property:

figure.name: Converting the PARTICIPANT-TYPE property

section.name: PERCENT-COMPLETE
section.t: The PERCENT-COMPLETE property in a VTODO component converts to the "percentComplete" property of the Task object.

A Task object which has the "method" property set might represent an iTIP reply of one of the participants in the object. In this case the value of the "percentComplete" property in the Task also converts to the percentComplete of that Participant object, which represents the participant from which the iTIP reply originated.
The PERCENT-COMPLETE property in a PARTICIPANT component converts to the "percentComplete" property of the Participant object.
The following examples illustrate how to convert the PERCENT-COMPLETE property:

figure.name: Converting the PERCENT-COMPLETE property in a VEVENT component
Converting the PERCENT-COMPLETE property in a PARTICIPANT component

section.name: PRIORITY
section.t: The PRIORITY property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to the "priority" property of the Event or Task object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the PRIORITY property:

figure.name: Converting the PRIORITY property

section.name: PRODID
section.t: The PRODID property in a VCALENDAR component converts to the "prodId" property of the Group object, and to the "prodId" property of all Event or Task objects that are listed in the Group object's entries property.
The property value converts verbatim.
The following example illustrates how to convert the PRODID property:

figure.name: Converting the PRODID property

section.name: RDATE
section.t: The RDATE property of type DATE or DATE-TIME in a VEVENT, VTODO, DAYLIGHT or STANDARD component converts to a PatchObject value. The converted object is set in the "recurrenceOverrides" property of the Event, Task, or TimeZoneRule object.

The property value converts to the key in the "recurrenceOverrides" property value. See how to convert DATE and DATE-TIME values. For Event Task objects, the date-time MUST be relative to the timezone identified by the "timeZone" property, for TimeZoneRule objects the date-time is relative to the UTC offset specified in the "offsetFrom" property. The PatchObject value MUST be an empty JSON object.
An RDATE property of value type PERIOD does not convert to a standard JSCalendar element. Implementations MAY convert it to the "iCalComponent" property of the Event, Task, or TimeZoneRule object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the RDATE property:

figure.name: Converting the RDATE property

section.name: RECURRENCE-ID
section.t: The RECURRENCE-ID property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to the "recurrenceId" property of the Event or Task object. The timezone identifier of the RECURRENCE-ID property converts to the "recurrenceIdTimeZone" property.
See how to convert DATE and DATE-TIME values.
The RANGE parameter does not convert to a standard JSCalendar element. Implementations MAY preserve it in the iCalComponent property.
See for further requirements and examples.

section.name: RELATED-TO
section.t: The RELATED-TO property in a VEVENT, VTODO, or VALARM component converts to a Relation object. The converted object is set in the "relatedTo" property of the Event or Task object, or the Alert object.

The property value in a VEVENT or VTODO converts as-is to the key of the Relation object in the "relatedTo" property. The property value in a VALARM converts to the same value as the key of that Alert object, which represents the VALARM component having that property value set in the UID property. Any RELTYPE parameters convert to the "relations" property in that Relation object. The parameter values convert in lowercase.
The GAP parameter does not convert to a standard JSCalendar element. Implementations MAY convert it to the "iCalProperty" property of the Relation object.
The following examples illustrate how to convert the RELATED-TO property:

figure.name: Converting the RELATED-TO property in a VEVENT
Converting the RELATED-TO property in a VALARM
figure.sourcecode: BEGIN:VEVENT ... BEGIN:VALARM UID:8297C37D-BA2D-4476-91AE-C1EAA364F8E1 TRIGGER:-PT15M DESCRIPTION:Event reminder ACTION:DISPLAY ACKNOWLEDGED:20210302T151514Z END:VALARM ... BEGIN:VALARM UID:DE7B5C34-83FF-47FE-BE9E-FF41AE6DD097 TRIGGER;VALUE=DATE-TIME:20210302T152000Z RELATED-TO;RELTYPE=SNOOZE:8297C37D-BA2D-4476-91AE-C1EAA364F8E1 DESCRIPTION:Event reminder ACTION:DISPLAY END:VALARM ...

section.name: REQUEST-STATUS
section.t: The REQUEST-STATUS property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to the "requestStatus" property of the Event or Task object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the REQUEST-STATUS property:

figure.name: Converting the REQUEST-STATUS property

section.name: RRULE
section.t: The RRULE property in a VEVENT, VTODO, DAYLIGHT or STANDARD component converts to a RecurrenceRule object. The converted object is set in the "recurrenceRules" property of the Event, Task, or TimeZoneRule object.
The RECUR value data type converts to a RecurrenceRule object as follows:

table.name: Converting the RECUR value type to a RecurrenceRule object

section.t: The string values of the FREQ, WKST, RSCALE convert to lowercase. The UNTIL part in a VEVENT or VTODO converts to a LocalDateTime value relative to the timezone of the Event or Task, or to floating time for the TimeZoneRule object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the RRULE property:

figure.name: Example for converting the RRULE property

section.name: SEQUENCE
section.t: The SEQUENCE property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to the "sequence" property of the Event or Task object. The SEQUENCE property in a PARTICIPANT component converts to the "scheduleSequence" property of the Participant object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the SEQUENCE property:

figure.name: Example for converting the SEQUENCE property

section.name: STATUS
section.t:
The STATUS property in a VEVENT component converts to the "status" property of the Event object.
The STATUS property in a VTODO component converts to the "progress" property of the Task object.
The property value converts in lowercase.
The following examples illustrate how to convert the STATUS property:

figure.name: Example for converting the STATUS property in a VEVENT component
Example for converting the STATUS property in a VTODO component

section.name: SOURCE
section.t: The SOURCE property in a VCALENDAR component converts to the "source" property of the Group object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the SOURCE property:

figure.name: Example for converting the SOURCE property

section.name: STRUCTURED-DATA
section.t: The STRUCTURED-DATA property of type URI or BINARY in a VEVENT, VTODO, VCALENDAR, VRESOURCE, PARTICIPANT, or VLOCATION component converts to a Link object. The converted object is set in the "links" property of the Event, Task, Group, Participant, or Location object.
The property value converts to the "href" property of the Link object. A value of type URI converts as-is. See how to convert a BINARY value.
Its parameters convert as follows:
Implementations MAY preserve the fact that the Link object got converted from a STRUCTURED-DATA property. To do so, they MUST set the iCalProperty on the Link object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the STRUCTURED-DATA property:

figure.name: Converting the STRUCTURED-DATA property

section.name: STYLED-DESCRIPTION
section.t: The STYLED-DESCRIPTION property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to the "description" property of the Event or Task object under the following conditions:

ul.li: The property value type MUST be TEXT.
The FMTTYPE parameter either MUST NOT be set, or its value MUST be a media type with top-level type "text".
Its DERIVED parameter value MUST NOT be TRUE. If the value is TRUE, then another property in the same component is expected to contain its description.

section.t: If these conditions are not met, implementations MAY preserve the property in the "iCalComponent" property.
Its parameters convert as follows:
The following example illustrates how to convert the STYLED-DESCRIPTION property:

figure.name: Converting the STYLED-DESCRIPTION property

section.name: SUMMARY
section.t: The SUMMARY property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to the "title" property of the Event or Task object.
The SUMMARY property in a PARTICIPANT component converts to the "name" property.
The following examples illustrate how to convert the SUMMARY property:

figure.name: Converting the SUMMARY property in a VEVENT
Converting the SUMMARY property in a PARTICIPANT

section.name: TRANSP
section.t: The TRANSP property in a VEVENT or VTODO component converts to the "freeBusyStatus" property of the Event or Task object.
Its values convert as follows:
The following example illustrates how to convert the TRANSP property:

figure.name: Converting the TRANSP property

section.name: TRIGGER
section.t: The TRIGGER property in a VALARM component converts to either an AbsoluteTrigger or OffsetTrigger object. The converted object is set in the "trigger" property of the Alert object.

A property of value type DURATION converts an OffsetTrigger object. The property value converts to its offset property. A value of type DATE-TIME converts to an AbsoluteTrigger object. The property value converts to its when property.
Its parameters convert as follows:
The following examples illustrate how to convert the TRIGGER property:

figure.name: Converting the TRIGGER property to an OffsetTrigger
Converting the TRIGGER property to an AbsoluteTrigger

section.name: TZID
section.t: The TZID property in a VTIMEZONE component converts to the "tzId" property of the TimeZone object.
See for an example.

section.name: TZID-ALIAS-OF
section.t: The TZID-ALIAS-OF property in a VTIMEZONE component converts to an entry in the "aliases" property of the TimeZone object.
See for an example.

section.name: TZNAME
section.t: The TZNAME property in a DAYLIGHT or STANDARD component converts to an entry in the "names" property of the TimeZoneRule object.
See for an example.

section.name: TZOFFSETFROM
section.t: The TZOFFSETFROM property in a DAYLIGHT or STANDARD component converts to the "offsetFrom" property of the TimeZoneRule object.
See for an example.

section.name: TZOFFSETTO
section.t: The TZOFFSETTO property in a DAYLIGHT or STANDARD component converts to the "offsetTo" property of the TimeZoneRule object.
See for an example.

section.name: TZUNTIL
section.t: The TZUNTIL property in a VTIMEZONE component converts to the "validUntil" property of the TimeZone object.
See how to convert DATE and DATE-TIME values.
See for an example.

section.name: TZURL
section.t: The TZURL property in a VTIMEZONE component converts to the "url" property of the TimeZone object.
See for an example.

section.name: UID
section.t: The UID property in a VEVENT, VTODO, or VCALENDAR component converts to the "uid" property of the Event, Task, or Group object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the UID property:

figure.name: Converting the UID property

section.name: URL
section.t: The URL property in a VEVENT, VTODO, VCALENDAR, or PARTICIPANT component converts to a Link object. The converted object is set in the "links" property of the Event, Task, Group, or Participant object.
The property value converts to the "href" property of the Link object.
Implementations MAY preserve the fact that the Link object got converted from a URL property. To do so, they MUST set the iCalProperty on the Link object.
The following example illustrates how to convert the URL property:

figure.name: Converting the IMAGE property

section.name: Alert
section.t: The Alert object converts to a VALARM component.
Its properties convert as follows:
Remarks:

li.t: The value of the RELATED-TO property is the UID property value of that VALARM component, to which the related Alert object converts to. Consequently, the UID property for such a VALARM MUST be set, otherwise the UID property SHOULD be set.

section.name: Event and Task
section.t: The Event object converts to a VEVENT component, the Task object converts to a VTODO component.

The following table defines how to convert properties that are common to both the Event and Task object types. and later in this section define how to convert properties specific to either Event or Task objects.

table.name: Properties of the Event and Task object

tr.td: RDATE, EXDATE or recurrence override component

section.t: Remarks:

li.t: The descriptionContentType property value determines if the "description" property converts to the DESCRIPTION or STYLED-DESCRIPTION property. A description of content type "text/plain" converts to the DESCRIPTION property. Any other description converts to a STYLED-DESCRIPTION; in this case, a plain text version of the rich-text description SHOULD be set in the DESCRIPTION property and its DERIVED parameter MUST be set to "TRUE". How to derive plain text from rich-text is implementation-specific.

The entries in the "recurrenceOverrides" property convert depending on the contents of the PatchObject value. A PatchObject that sets the "excluded" property to "true" converts to an EXDATE property for the date-time of that recurrence instance. An empty PatchObject converts to an RDATE property. Any other PatchObject converts to a recurrence override component in the embedding VCALENDAR component.

The replyTo property converts to the ORGANIZER property. If the "replyTo" property value only defines a single scheduling method then the URI value of that method converts to the ORGANIZER property value. If the "replyTo" property defines multiple scheduling methods, and a Participant object with a calendarAddress property value matching one of the replyTo URIs exists in the same Event or Task, then the URI matching the "calendarAddress" property converts to the ORGANIZER property value. Otherwise choosing the ORGANIZER property value is implementation-specific. TBD how to convert other replyTo methods.

section.t: Properties specific to the Event object type convert to iCalendar properties as follows:
Properties specific to the Task object type convert to iCalendar properties as follows:

section.name: Group
section.t: The Group object converts to a VCALENDAR component.
Its properties convert as follows:

td.t: Event and Task object, and remarks below

section.t: Remarks:

li.t: The prodId property value of the Group object is expected to be equal to the "prodId" property value of all the Group entries. They all convert to the same, single PRODID property in the VCALENDAR component. How to convert unequal prodId property values is implementation-specific.
The method property value in all the Group entries is expected to be equal. How to convert entries with unequal method property values is implementation-specific.

section.name: Link
section.t: The Link object converts either an ATTACH property, an IMAGE property, a LINK property, a STRUCTURED-DATA property, or an URL property. Which iCalendar property to choose is implementation-specific. As a guideline:

ul.li: Choose IMAGE, if the "display" property is set or the "rel" property value is "icon".
Choose LINK, if the "rel" property is set to any other value.
Choose URL, if only the "href" property is set and its value links to a dynamic rendition of the calendar object.
TBD - Choose STRUCTURED-DATA, if the "schema" property is set.

section.t: The href property converts to the "iCalendar" property value. The other Link properties convert as follows:
Remarks:

ul.li: The LINKREL parameter SHOULD be omitted if the Link object converts to an IMAGE property and the "rel" property value is "icon".

section.name: Location
section.t: The Location object converts to either a LOCATION, GEO, or DTEND property, or it converts to a VLOCATION component. Which iCalendar element to choose is implementation-specific. As a guideline:

ul.li: Choose LOCATION, if only the "title" property is set and the iCalendar component does not already contain a LOCATION property. The title property converts to the LOCATION property value.

Choose GEO, if only the "coordinates" property is set and the iCalendar component does not already contain a GEO property. The coordinates property converts to the GEO property value. TBD - How to convert arbitrary geo: URIs?

Choose DTEND, if the embedding object is an Event, only the timeZone and the relativeTo properties are set, the "relativeTo" property value is "end" and the iCalendar component does not already contain a DTEND property. The timeZone property converts to the TZID parameter of the DTEND property. The duration of the embedding Event object determines the DTEND property value.

section.t: Implementations MAY convert one of the Location objects that convert to a VLOCATION also to the LOCATION property; converting the title or description property to the LOCATION property value is a reasonable choice. The DERIVED parameter MUST be set on the LOCATION property.
The properties convert to a VLOCATION component as follows:

section.name: Participant
section.t: The Participant object either converts to one of an ATTENDEE property, a PARTICIPANT component, or a VRESOURCE component; or it converts to both an ATTENDEE property and a PARTICIPANT component:

li.t: It converts to an ATTENDEE property if at least one of the calendarAddress or sendTo properties is set. The calendarAddress property converts to the ATTENDEE property value, if set; otherwise one of the scheduling methods in the "sendTo" property converts to the ATTENDEE property value.

It converts to a PARTICIPANT component if it converts to an ATTENDEE property but not all of its properties convert to ATTENDEE property parameters as depicted in . In this case the CALENDAR-ADDRESS property value of the PARTICIPANT MUST be set to the ATTENDEE property value. Alternatively, the Participant object also converts to a PARTICIPANT component if it does not convert to an ATTENDEE property but its kind property value is unequal to "resource".
It converts to a VRESOURCE component if it does not convert to an ATTENDEE property and its kind property value is "resource".

section.t: The following Participant properties convert to the ATTENDEE property. How to convert these properties if the Participant does not convert to an ATTENDEE is implementation-specific.

table.name: Properties of the Participant object that convert to the ATTENDEE property

tr.td: ROLE, or PARTICIPANT-TYPE property of the PARTICIPANT component

section.t: Remarks:

li.t: The "optional" role converts to the "OPT-PARTICIPANT" ROLE parameter value, the "chair" role to "CHAIR", "informational" to "NON-PARTICIPANT". The "attendee" role does not convert to the ROLE parameter, it is implied by the ATTENDEE property. The "owner" role does not convert to the ROLE parameter, if the property value of the ATTENDEE is equal to the value of the ORGANIZER property in the same component. All other roles require a PARTICIPANT component and convert to the PARTICIPANT-TYPE property in that component.
The progress property converts to the PARTSTAT parameter as outlined in .

section.t: The following Participant properties convert to the PARTICIPANT or VRESOURCE component:

table.name: Properties of the Participant object that convert to the PARTICIPANT or VRESOURCE component

section.name: TimeZone
section.t: The TimeZone object converts to a VTIMEZONE component.
Its properties convert as follows:
The TimeZoneRule object converts to a DAYLIGHT or STANDARD component.
Its properties convert as follows:

section.name: VirtualLocation
section.t: The VirtualLocation object converts to a CONFERENCE property.
The uri property converts to the CONFERENCE property value. Its other properties convert as follows:

section.name: JSCALID
section.t: TBD

section.name: JSCALID
section.t: TBD

section.name: JSPROP
section.t: TBD

dl.dd: This is the date and time when the task was completed.

dd.t: This contains information about an iCalendar component that got partially or fully converted to JSCalendar. It allows for preserving the name of the iCalendar component and some or all of its properties and subcomponents.
An ICalComponent object has the following properties:

dl.dd: This specifies the type of this object. This MUST be ICalComponent.
This is the name of the iCalendar component in lowercase.
This contains subcomponents of the iCalendar component. The value MUST be a list of iCalendar components formatted in jCal as defined in .

dd.t: This contains conversion-related information about the component's properties that got partially or fully converted to JSCalendar. Each key defines the path to a property of the JSCalendar object on which the "iCalComponent" property is set on. The value for each key contains information about the "iCalendar" property which converted to the "object" property located at that key (see ).

The key MUST be a valid key of a PatchObject as defined in . The key MUST NOT point into a nested property, unless there is no way to otherwise preserve the "iCalendar" property elements. For example, if a VEVENT contains an ATTENDEE property, then any iCalendar information about the ATTENDEE property MUST be set in the "iCalProperty" property of the converted Participant object (see ). In contrast, information about a RDATE property contained in a VEVENT would be located by a key pointing into the recurrenceOverrides property of the Event object (see ).

dl.dd: This contains properties of the iCalendar component. The value MUST be a list of iCalendar properties formatted in jCal as defined in .

dd.t: This contains conversion-related information about an iCalendar property that got partially or fully converted to JSCalendar. It allows for preserving the name of the "iCalendar" property and some or all of its parameters.
An ICalProperty object has the following properties:

dl.dd: This specifies the type of this object. This MUST be ICalProperty.
This is the name of the "iCalendar" property in lowercase.
This is the name of the "iCalendar" property value type in lowercase.
This contains parameters of the "iCalendar" property. The value MUST comply with iCalendar parameters formatted in jCal as defined in .

This represents locations associated with the participant. In contrast to the single-valued "locationId" property, this allows for associating multiple locations with the Participant object, and to express that a location only is relevant for this participant.

dd.t: This property represents the SCHEDULE-AGENT parameter specified on an ORGANIZER property. In the context of scheduling as outlined in , a scheduling client can set this property to indicate who is responsible for sending scheduling messages to the organizer in the "replyTo" property. The same values as for the "scheduleAgent" property of the Participant object are allowed, the "none" value indicates that no scheduling message is to be sent to the organizer. The property MUST NOT be preserved in the JSCalendar object on the server or appear in a scheduling message. If this property is set, then the "replyTo" property MUST be set.

This property represents the SCHEDULE-FORCE-SEND parameter specified on an ORGANIZER property. In the context of scheduling as outlined in , a scheduling client can set this property to true to request that the server send a scheduling message to the organizer defined in the "replyTo" property, when it would not normally do so (e.g., if no significant change is made to the object or the scheduleAgent is set to "client"). The property MUST NOT be preserved in the JSCalendar object on the server or appear in a scheduling message. If this property is set, then the "replyTo" property MUST be set.

This property represents the SCHEDULE-STATUS parameter specified on an ORGANIZER property. In the context of scheduling as outlined in , the scheduling client or server can set this property to a list of status codes, returned from processing the most recent scheduling message sent to the organizer defined in the "replyTo" property. The status codes MUST be valid "statcode" values as defined in the ABNF in . Servers MUST only add or change this property when they send a scheduling message to the organizer. Clients SHOULD NOT change or remove this property if it was provided by the server. Clients MAY add, change, or remove the property for participants where the client is handling the scheduling. This property MUST NOT be included in scheduling messages.

section.name: rel (Link)
section.t: This document modifies the definition of the "rel" property of the Link object. The original specification in restricts that its values MUST be a registered relation type as defined in . The new definition allows the value also to be an extension relation type to improve interoperability with the LINKREL parameter in iCalendar. The new definition of the Link "rel" property is:

dd.t: This identifies the relation of the linked resource to the object. If set, the value MUST either be a registered relation type or an extension relation type, as defined in .

section.name: Discrepancies between iCalendar and JSCalendar
section.t: This section highlights iCalendar and JSCalendar elements for which no conversion rule to a standard element is defined in this document. This is informational; implementations MAY convert these elements, for example by use of the special-purpose properties defined in this document, or some vendor-specific extension properties. Alternatively newer standards might define new standard elements and register them at IANA.

section.name: Components
section.t: The following components do not convert to a standard element in JSCalendar:

section.name: Properties by Component
section.t: The following components are defined to contain the listed properties. But these properties do not convert to a standard JSCalendar element.

section.name: Properties by Value Type
section.t: The following properties convert to a standard JSCalendar element for some other value type, but they do not for the listed value types.

section.name: Parameters by Property
section.t: The following properties are defined to contain the listed parameters. But these parameters do not convert to a standard JSCalendar element.

section.name: Common Properties
section.t: The following properties are defined in for the Event, Task and (with restrictions) Group objects, but they do not convert to a standard iCalendar element.

section.name: Participant Properties
section.t: The following properties are defined for the Participant object but do not convert to standard Calendar elements.
